topic: Crush Negative Self-Talk with Evidence Hunting

dialog.text: I keep telling myself, 'I'm just not good enough'—how do I shut that voice up?
dialog.instructions: Anxious, breathy, slightly rushed; rising intonation at the end; vulnerable but seeking help.

dialog.text: Start by treating that voice like a claim you can test. What exactly does it say if you say it out loud?
dialog.instructions: Calm, gentle, measured pace; warm tone, reassuring; slow enough to be grounding.

dialog.text: It says, 'I always mess up presentations.' Is that something I can test?
dialog.instructions: Hesitant, quiet, slightly skeptical; rising question tone; searching for permission to be logical.

dialog.text: Absolutely. Ask: what's the evidence for 'always'? And what's the evidence against it?
dialog.instructions: Encouraging, clear, slightly upbeat; steady rhythm that invites action.

dialog.text: Well… I stumbled once. But I also had a talk last month where people praised me and the Q&A went fine.
dialog.instructions: Slow, reflective; relief mixing with surprise; softer cadence as confidence returns.

dialog.text: 'Always' is a red flag. Your single stumble is evidence for the worry; the praise and strong Q&A are counterevidence. Which side carries more weight?
dialog.instructions: Firm but kind, guiding; slightly faster to nudge toward a conclusion.

dialog.text: So instead of 'I always mess up,' try: 'Sometimes I struggle with presentations, but I also give good ones and can prepare better next time.'
dialog.instructions: Reassuring, steady, empowering; speak the balanced sentence slowly so the listener can absorb it.

dialog.text: That already feels calmer. What do I do when the old voice screams again?
dialog.instructions: Curious, hopeful, quieter; a hint of eagerness to learn a practical trick.

dialog.text: Make a tiny habit: before a big moment, list 3 wins, 1 lesson, and one concrete next step. Read it aloud. It trains your brain to favor evidence over fear.
dialog.instructions: Practical, brisk, motivational; upbeat tone that makes the method feel doable.

dialog.text: Try evidence hunting this week—share one counterexample to your toughest self-claim in the comments or journal it tonight. What did you find?
dialog.instructions: Inviting, warm, slightly bright; call-to-action energy, friendly and encouraging.
